item.title: WDM Wavelength Services Offer Expandability

item.title: Fiber Ethernet WAN Bandwidth Advantages
item.description: Larger companies often need more internet bandwidth than what’s typically offered through standard copper wire connections. While fiber optic cables provide a solution with almost limitless bandwidth, finding a cost-effective option is key. Businesses already utilizing fiber optic bandwidth might be leasing older SONET/SDH services like OC3, OC12, or OC48 for their wide area network needs. These traditional telecom services, originally designed for high-volume phone calls, have been adapted to handle today’s demand for high-bandwidth data connections.

item.title: Bandwidth Management Gets Easier With Ethernet
item.description: The unpredictable nature of bandwidth demand, with its constant fluctuations and potential for rapid growth, presents a challenge for IT managers seeking to balance sufficient resources with cost-effectiveness. Traditional procurement processes, designed for less dynamic times, involve lengthy steps from identifying needs to service activation, making it difficult to adapt quickly to changing bandwidth requirements. This problem is exacerbated by legacy telecom services like T1 lines or OC connections, which offer fixed bandwidth levels.

item.title: Fiber Optic ISP
item.description: Internet service used to rely on dial-up connections, but it has advanced significantly since then. Today, medium-sized businesses are now transitioning to fiber optic internet service providers, a technology already embraced by larger corporations. Residential fiber optic internet, like Verizon’s FiOS, offers high speeds, with Google soon to introduce even faster Gigabit service. Business broadband connections, however, have already surpassed Gigabit speeds, with 10 Gbps becoming increasingly common. The technology is well-established, leaving businesses to determine their bandwidth needs and locations.

item.title: 600 Mbps Ethernet vs OC12 SONET
item.description: Companies that need bandwidth in the fractional Gigabit range have often relied on OC12 SONET fiber optic service. While it remains a solid high-speed choice, it’s worth considering 600 Mbps Ethernet as well. Comparing these two options might yield some surprising results. OC-12 (622 Mbps) is the next tier up from OC-3 (155 Mbps) in the SONET optical carrier hierarchy. This service is widely available in Metropolitan Area Networks (MANs) and as a dedicated internet access connection for mid-sized internet service providers.
